speaker: GOWER
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: SCENE I. London. KING RICHARD II's palace.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Enter KING RICHARD II, JOHN OF GAUNT, with other Nobles and Attendants

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Old John of Gaunt, time-honour'd Lancaster,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Hast thou, according to thy oath and band,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Brought hither Henry Hereford thy bold son,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Here to make good the boisterous late appeal,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Which then our leisure would not let us hear,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Against the Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Mowbray?

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: I have, my liege.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Tell me, moreover, hast thou sounded him,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: If he appeal the duke on ancient malice;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Or worthily, as a good subject should,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: On some known ground of treachery in him?

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: As near as I could sift him on that argument,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: On some apparent danger seen in him

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Aim'd at your highness, no inveterate malice.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Then call them to our presence; face to face,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And frowning brow to brow, ourselves will hear

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The accuser and the accused freely speak:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: High-stomach'd are they both, and full of ire,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: In rage deaf as the sea, hasty as fire.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Enter HENRY BOLINGBROKE and THOMAS MOWBRAY

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Many years of happy days befal

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: My gracious sovereign, my most loving liege!

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Each day still better other's happiness;

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Until the heavens, envying earth's good hap,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Add an immortal title to your crown!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: We thank you both: yet one but flatters us,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: As well appeareth by the cause you come;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Namely to appeal each other of high treason.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Cousin of Hereford, what dost thou object

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Against the Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Mowbray?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: First, heaven be the record to my speech!

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: In the devotion of a subject's love,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Tendering the precious safety of my prince,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And free from other misbegotten hate,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Come I appellant to this princely presence.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Now, Thomas Mowbray, do I turn to thee,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And mark my greeting well; for what I speak

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: My body shall make good upon this earth,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Or my divine soul answer it in heaven.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Thou art a traitor and a miscreant,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Too good to be so and too bad to live,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Since the more fair and crystal is the sky,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: The uglier seem the clouds that in it fly.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Once more, the more to aggravate the note,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: With a foul traitor's name stuff I thy throat;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And wish, so please my sovereign, ere I move,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: What my tongue speaks my right drawn sword may prove.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Let not my cold words here accuse my zeal:

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: 'Tis not the trial of a woman's war,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: The bitter clamour of two eager tongues,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Can arbitrate this cause betwixt us twain;

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: The blood is hot that must be cool'd for this:

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Yet can I not of such tame patience boast

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: As to be hush'd and nought at all to say:

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: First, the fair reverence of your highness curbs me

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: From giving reins and spurs to my free speech;

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Which else would post until it had return'd

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: These terms of treason doubled down his throat.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Setting aside his high blood's royalty,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: And let him be no kinsman to my liege,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: I do defy him, and I spit at him;

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Call him a slanderous coward and a villain:

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Which to maintain I would allow him odds,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: And meet him, were I tied to run afoot

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Even to the frozen ridges of the Alps,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Or any other ground inhabitable,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Where ever Englishman durst set his foot.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Mean time let this defend my loyalty,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: By all my hopes, most falsely doth he lie.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Pale trembling coward, there I throw my gage,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Disclaiming here the kindred of the king,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And lay aside my high blood's royalty,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Which fear, not reverence, makes thee to except.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: If guilty dread have left thee so much strength

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: As to take up mine honour's pawn, then stoop:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: By that and all the rites of knighthood else,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Will I make good against thee, arm to arm,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: What I have spoke, or thou canst worse devise.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: I take it up; and by that sword I swear

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Which gently laid my knighthood on my shoulder,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: I'll answer thee in any fair degree,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Or chivalrous design of knightly trial:

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: And when I mount, alive may I not light,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: If I be traitor or unjustly fight!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: What doth our cousin lay to Mowbray's charge?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: It must be great that can inherit us

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: So much as of a thought of ill in him.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Look, what I speak, my life shall prove it true;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: That Mowbray hath received eight thousand nobles

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: In name of lendings for your highness' soldiers,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: The which he hath detain'd for lewd employments,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Like a false traitor and injurious villain.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Besides I say and will in battle prove,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Or here or elsewhere to the furthest verge

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: That ever was survey'd by English eye,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: That all the treasons for these eighteen years

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Complotted and contrived in this land

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Fetch from false Mowbray their first head and spring.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Further I say and further will maintain

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Upon his bad life to make all this good,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: That he did plot the Duke of Gloucester's death,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Suggest his soon-believing adversaries,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And consequently, like a traitor coward,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Sluiced out his innocent soul through streams of blood:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Which blood, like sacrificing Abel's, cries,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Even from the tongueless caverns of the earth,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: To me for justice and rough chastisement;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And, by the glorious worth of my descent,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: This arm shall do it, or this life be spent.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: How high a pitch his resolution soars!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Thomas of Norfolk, what say'st thou to this?

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: O, let my sovereign turn away his face

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: And bid his ears a little while be deaf,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Till I have told this slander of his blood,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: How God and good men hate so foul a liar.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Mowbray, impartial are our eyes and ears:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Were he my brother, nay, my kingdom's heir,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: As he is but my father's brother's son,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Now, by my sceptre's awe, I make a vow,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Such neighbour nearness to our sacred blood

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Should nothing privilege him, nor partialize

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The unstooping firmness of my upright soul:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: He is our subject, Mowbray; so art thou:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Free speech and fearless I to thee allow.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Then, Bolingbroke, as low as to thy heart,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Through the false passage of thy throat, thou liest.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Three parts of that receipt I had for Calais

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Disbursed I duly to his highness' soldiers;

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: The other part reserved I by consent,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: For that my sovereign liege was in my debt

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Upon remainder of a dear account,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Since last I went to France to fetch his queen:

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Now swallow down that lie. For Gloucester's death,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: I slew him not; but to my own disgrace

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Neglected my sworn duty in that case.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: For you, my noble Lord of Lancaster,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: The honourable father to my foe

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Once did I lay an ambush for your life,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: A trespass that doth vex my grieved soul

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: But ere I last received the sacrament

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: I did confess it, and exactly begg'd

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Your grace's pardon, and I hope I had it.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: This is my fault: as for the rest appeall'd,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: It issues from the rancour of a villain,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: A recreant and most degenerate traitor

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Which in myself I boldly will defend;

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: And interchangeably hurl down my gage

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Upon this overweening traitor's foot,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: To prove myself a loyal gentleman

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Even in the best blood chamber'd in his bosom.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: In haste whereof, most heartily I pray

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Your highness to assign our trial day.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Wrath-kindled gentlemen, be ruled by me;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Let's purge this choler without letting blood:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: This we prescribe, though no physician;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Deep malice makes too deep incision;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Forget, forgive; conclude and be agreed;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Our doctors say this is no month to bleed.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Good uncle, let this end where it begun;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: We'll calm the Duke of Norfolk, you your son.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: To be a make-peace shall become my age:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Throw down, my son, the Duke of Norfolk's gage.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And, Norfolk, throw down his.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: When, Harry, when?

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Obedience bids I should not bid again.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Norfolk, throw down, we bid; there is no boot.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Myself I throw, dread sovereign, at thy foot.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: My life thou shalt command, but not my shame:

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: The one my duty owes; but my fair name,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Despite of death that lives upon my grave,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: To dark dishonour's use thou shalt not have.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: I am disgraced, impeach'd and baffled here,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Pierced to the soul with slander's venom'd spear,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: The which no balm can cure but his heart-blood

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Which breathed this poison.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Rage must be withstood:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Give me his gage: lions make leopards tame.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Yea, but not change his spots: take but my shame.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: And I resign my gage. My dear dear lord,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: The purest treasure mortal times afford

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Is spotless reputation: that away,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Men are but gilded loam or painted clay.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: A jewel in a ten-times-barr'd-up chest

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Is a bold spirit in a loyal breast.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Mine honour is my life; both grow in one:

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Take honour from me, and my life is done:

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Then, dear my liege, mine honour let me try;

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: In that I live and for that will I die.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Cousin, throw up your gage; do you begin.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: O, God defend my soul from such deep sin!

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Shall I seem crest-fall'n in my father's sight?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Or with pale beggar-fear impeach my height

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Before this out-dared dastard? Ere my tongue

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Shall wound my honour with such feeble wrong,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Or sound so base a parle, my teeth shall tear

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: The slavish motive of recanting fear,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And spit it bleeding in his high disgrace,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Where shame doth harbour, even in Mowbray's face.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Exit JOHN OF GAUNT

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: We were not born to sue, but to command;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Which since we cannot do to make you friends,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Be ready, as your lives shall answer it,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: At Coventry, upon Saint Lambert's day:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: There shall your swords and lances arbitrate

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The swelling difference of your settled hate:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Since we can not atone you, we shall see

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Justice design the victor's chivalry.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Lord marshal, command our officers at arms

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Be ready to direct these home alarms.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Exeunt
